channel.title: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD)
channel.description: Daily Feed (Updated 9 AM BD) generated by script

item.title: Germany commits €1 billion to flagship COP30 forest fund
item.description: After weeks of uncertainty, Germany is in: Berlin will invest €1B in Brazil’s new Tropical Forest Forever Facility.

item.title: G20 panel calls for a new debt refinancing plan for low-income nations
item.description: A new Africa debt proposal has landed at the G20, and will be considered by heads of state at the Leaders’ Summit this weekend.

item.title: Sen. Grassley probes top foundation's China funding, nonprofit status
item.description: The Gates Foundation and Ford Foundation defend compliance with U.S. tax law as Senate inquiry cites reports of CCP-linked giving.

item.title: Can AI safely support mental health?
item.description: Bilal Mateen, Miranda Wolpert, and Christelna Reynecke join Devex’s Catherine Cheney for a special edition podcast on artificial intelligence’s role in supporting mental health.

item.title: Finland's Pekka Haavisto: No 'magic stick' to fix UN refugee funding gap
item.description: Former Finnish minister joins race to serve as U.N. high commissioner for refugees.

item.title: Civil Society Warns of New Land Grabs as World Bank Pushes for Tenure Reforms in Africa
item.description: The idea of land abundance is a colonial fiction that refuses to die. Our research shows that Africa’s lands are already intensively used and deeply valued by millions of rural people. Professor Ruth Hall, Director–PLAAS at the University of the Western Cape.

item.title: Africa’s Famed Forest Is Damaged by War, but a New Plan Could Help Restore It
item.description: While the main warring parties — M23 rebels and Congolese national army — struggle to silence their weapons in the eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo, despite continuing peace initiatives, the region’s civilians continue to suffer from the conflict as the M23 still occupy North and South Kivu provinces. The region’s abundant biodiversity is also ... Read more

item.title: Explainer: Inside COP30’s 11th Hour Negotiations for Legacy-Building Belém Climate Deal
item.description: The COP30 Presidency is urging all “negotiators to join in a true mutirão—a collective mobilization of minds, hearts, and hands,” saying this approach helps “accelerate the pace, bridge divides, and focus not on what separates us, but on what unites us in purpose and humanity.”

item.title: The Uneven Race of Mexican Protected Areas against Climate Change
item.description: Ezequiel Sánchez, a 63-year-old Mexican fisherman, owes everything to the sea. “My life, my work, my family,” he says, pointing around his office, which is located just a block from the ocean in Puerto Morelos town, in the southeastern state of Quintana Roo, Mexico. Sánchez, who is married and has one son and three daughters, […]

item.title: COP30 reporters' notebook: Day 10
item.description: On the ground at the 30th United Nations Climate Change Conference, Devex reporters deliver the latest updates.

item.title: Global south's TB diagnostics innovations are key to fight the epidemic
item.description: Opinion: As G7 aid cuts threaten TB programs, affordable diagnostics developed in the global south offer a path forward for high-burden countries to help close the testing gap and save lives.

item.title: Devex Dish: Welcome to the AgriZone, where the heat is on
item.description: Inside the fight over agribusiness at COP30, and experts urge governments to act on ultra-processed foods.

item.title: The world is fragmenting — Africa and Europe can still hold it together
item.description: Opinion: As a vital stabilizing axis, the Africa-Europe partnership must seize the opportunity for a necessary and urgent reset — one that could unlock $2.3 trillion in investment and solidify a shared future for the benefit of both continents, and the world.

item.title: How to get started as a global development consultant
item.description: During a recent digital event, veteran development consultants Jami Johnson Darkoh and Candela Iglesias Chiesa offered expert guidance on how to break into consulting in the development sector.

item.title: G20 reporter's notebook: Social Summit Day 2
item.description: The second day of the Social Summit has arrived, and civil society delegates are here to deliberate. What happens today will shape the G20 Social Summit's declaration, which will be delivered to South African President Cyril Ramaphosa on Thursday.

item.title: The U.S. President Doth Protest Too Much, Methinks
item.description: With the longest shutdown of the U.S. government now over, the White House, Congress, the media, and the public have shifted their attention to the contentious and highly political issue of releasing the files related to Jeffrey Epstein. The White House’s resistance to releasing Epstein-related documents brings to mind the famous line from Shakespeare’s Hamlet […]

item.title: Devex Newswire: New US health strategy positions African governments as customers
item.description: The "America First" global health strategy puts American companies at the center of Africa’s health market. Plus, a look at one of the candidates to lead the United Nation’s refugee work.

item.title: Olympic Truce: ‘Humanity can find common ground through sport’
item.description: Sport has always been more than a contest of strength or skill. At its best, it becomes a rare space where people meet as equals – a reminder, as the President of the UN General Assembly put it on Wednesday, that “even in times of division, humanity can find common ground through sport – and an enduring hope.”

item.title: Top Syria Envoy: Humanitarian situation is ‘extremely serious’
item.description: Nearly a year on from the fall of Assad, Syrians still lack many basic necessities as the transitional government works to shore up the economy and build social cohesion.

item.title: Deadly overnight attack in Ukraine condemned by senior UN officials
item.description: At least 25 people were killed and dozens more injured in a new wave of overnight strikes across Ukraine, the United Nations said on Wednesday.

item.title: UN calls for legal safeguards for AI in healthcare
item.description: Use of artificial intelligence (AI) is accelerating in healthcare – but basic legal safety nets that protect patients and health workers are lacking.

item.title: In the Amazon, a school becomes a beacon of climate resilience
item.description: The boat ride from Belém to Barcarena is a journey through shimmering waterways and emerald forest, where the Amazon meets the Atlantic in a sweep of beauty. But beneath the postcard-perfect scene, climate change is quietly rewriting the rules of life.

item.title: Ending violence against women ‘a matter of dignity, equality and human rights’
item.description: When Salma* was just 15, she was forced to get married, even though she wanted to stay in school and become a doctor someday.

item.title: Gaza: Displaced Palestinians dealing with the ‘death of dignity’, warns UNICEF
item.description: Living conditions for Gazans – particularly children – are still dire as temperatures drop and families return to bombed-out homes as the fragile ceasefire holds, UN aid workers said on Wednesday.

item.title: The key talking points at COP30
item.description: From advancing the Baku-to-Belém Roadmap to Brazil’s initiative to curb deforestation, we examine the critical conversations defining COP30.

item.title: Why crop diversity is key for the future of food
item.description: Opinion: Crop diversity, nurtured over centuries, is eroding fast. A global gathering in Lima, Peru, will determine whether we can safeguard the genetic resources needed to feed future generations.

item.title: Devex Invested: At COP30, all eyes turn to private finance in adaptation push
item.description: New guarantees, debt-for-resilience deals, and the loss and damage fund signal a shift in how climate risk gets financed. Plus, get ready for the G20.

item.title: AI and the Future of Learning
item.description: “Sometimes the best way to grasp a concept,” says Chris Folayan, co-founder and executive officer of Luma Learn, “is to learn it in your native language.” Seventeen-year-old South African Simphiwe is one of more than 10,000 learners already using Luma Learn, an AI-powered tutor platform. For him, artificial intelligence isn’t an abstract idea: it is […]
